Award.AwardTitle: Workshop Proposal: Elliptic Curves over Q(\sqrt{5})
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop on elliptic curves over a real quadratic extension of the rational numbers will take place April 27-29, 2012 at the University of Illinois at Chicago. The organizers of this workshop are William Stein (University of Washington at Seattle) and Ramin Takloo-Bighash (University of Illinois at Chicago). The invited speakers are Jennifer Balakrishnan (Harvard), Jonathan Bober (University of Washington at Seattle), John Cremona (Warwick), Lassina Dembele (Warwick), Noam Elkies (Harvard), Edray Goins (Purdue), Matthew Greenberg (Calgary), Richard Pinch, Kenneth Ribet (UC Berkeley), William Stein (UW Seattle), Nike Vatsal (UBC), and John Voight (University of Vermont). This is part of the annual Oliver Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop at UIC. The theme of the workshop is the theoretical and computational aspects of elliptic curves over totally real fields, Hilbert modular forms, and the arithmetic of elliptic curves in general. The website of the workshop is http://www.math.uic.edu/~rtakloo/atkin2012.html

Elliptic curves are of fundamental interest in number theory. The theory of these objects over the field of rational numbers is starting to look like a coherent theory, but as soon as one steps away from rational numbers our understanding of these objects becomes extremely patchy. This workshop focuses on the theory of elliptic curves on a very simple field different from the field of rational numbers. We hope that bringing together experts working in the area would create an environment in which to exchange ideas and to start new projects which will hopefully lead to a better understanding of these fundamental objects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Elliptic curves are fundamental objects of interest in mathematics. They have many applications to various branches of mathematics, most notably in number theory where they have been used to tackle deep long standing problems such as the Fermat's Last Theorem. Recently they have also been used to develop cryptographic systems. Most of the theory of elliptic cuves has been developed over the rational numbers. Theoretical advances in number theory, and the increasing computational power of our computers give us tools to study elliptic cuves over other number systems, known as number fields. One of the simplest number fields in Q(square root{5}) which is the collection of real numbers of the form a + b squareroot{5} with a and b rational numbers.

The National Science Foundation grant DMS-1207199 was used to organize a workshop with the title of “Elliptic Curves over Q(square root{5})”. The organizers were William Stein (University of Washington) and Ramin Takloo-Bighash (UIC). This workshop was part of the annual Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop held at UIC in the memory of UIC’s professor emeritus Oliver Atkin. 

William Stein (University of Washington) delivered the Atkin Lecture on Friday April 27 at 3 PM. His lecture was attended by about 150 people. The workshop on Saturday and Sunday was attended by about 50 people, 28 of whom were supported by the NSF grant. Stein's lecture was followed by a workshop on Saturday and Sunday. There were a total of 13 lectures. The speakers were Jennifer Balakrishnan (Harvard), Jonathan Bober (University of Washington), John Cremona (Warwick), Lassina Dembele (Warwick), Noam Elkies (Harvard), Edray Goins (Purdue), Matthew Greenberg (Calgary), Richard Pinch (Cheltenham), Kenneth Ribet (Berkeley), William Stein (University of Washington), Nike Vatsal (British Columbia), and John Voight (University of Vermont). The basic theme of the conference was the theoretical and computational aspects of elliptic curves and modular forms over totally real fields. The abstracts of the lectures and the slide for many of the lectures are available at

 

http://www.math.uic.edu/~rtakloo/atkin2012.html

Intellectual Merits: The theme of the workshop was the theoretical and computational aspects of elliptic curves over totally real fields, Hilbert modular forms, and the arithmetic of elliptic curves in general.  bringing together experts working in the area created an environment in which to exchange ideas and to start new projects.   

Broader Impact:  Funding from the National Science Foundation made it possible for junior researchers, graduate students, and other mathematicians without travel funds to attend this exciting workshop. This was an excellent opportunity for them to interact with expert and be inspired for further work. Most of the lectures were videotaped, and were made available on the workshop website to make the lectures accessible to the mathematical community. The slides of talks were also made available on the same website.
